did.head: Collection Summary

descriptivenote.p: Collection material in English and Yiddish

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Recordings of interviews, conversations, social events, rehearsals, performances, and presentations by klezmer musicians and Yiddish folk singers collected primarily in New York City, Los Angeles, and Eastern Europe.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: In 2014, Michael Alpert sent the recordings to the Center for Traditional Music and Dance (CTMD) where Clara Byom digitized the sound recordings and cassette liners between 2014 and 2021.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Michael Alpert collection was processed by Maya Lerman and Sara Ludewig in 2023. Materials were arranged into the first six series by Clara Byom at CTMD, and Sara Ludewig later added additional series to better describe the large number of unsorted tapes. Maya Lerman and Sara Ludewig assigned each analog recording an AFC SR number, but retained the Alpert ID number for each recording.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p:
Related materials can be found in the
Center for Traditional Music and Dance collection (AFC 2014/044)
, to which Alpert contributed as a performer.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Michael Alpert collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Michael Alpert collection (AFC 2017/048), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Michael Alpert is a scholar, linguist, and performer whose work focuses on the expressive culture of Eastern European Jews in the late nineteenth, twentieth, and early twenty-first centuries in Europe and the United States. His former research affiliations include New York City's YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, the Center for Traditional Music and Dance, Oxford University, Columbia University, Yale University, and Indiana University. He was the 2015 recipient of a National Heritage Fellowship from the National Endowment for the Arts. In addition to his scholarly work on klezmer and Yiddish folk music, he is a performer with the ensembles Brave Old World and Kapelye where he performs primarily on violin, percussion, and accordion.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Michael Alpert collection includes field recordings of interviews, conversations, social events, rehearsals, and performances of klezmer music and Yiddish folk songs primarily in New York City, Los Angeles, and Eastern Europe. The collection focuses on the expressive culture of Eastern European Jews in the later nineteenth, twentieth, and early twenty-first centuries and documents immigrant generation and U.S. born practitioners from that period. With recordings in both English and Yiddish, the collection thoroughly documents aspects of vernacular culture and history, especially in light of the cataclysmic displacement and dispersion of Eastern European Jews in the twentieth century.
The analog materials that were digitized at CTMD are available as both WAV and MP3 files. Cassette liners were also digitized at CTMD and are available as PDF files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Michael Alpert collection is organized in 9 series:

item.ref: Series 5: Soviet Jewish Folk Arts Program recordings, 1982-1983
Series 8: Brave Old World and Michael Alpert's personal recordings, 1982-2003
Series 9: Miscellaneous recordings, performances, lectures, and interviews, 1979-2004

arrangement.p: Digital surrogates are labeled with the original ID number assigned by Alpert and are arranged by this ID number in their archival information package (AIP). Born-digital materials are arranged by their Alpert ID number in their AIP and are described at the item level in their respective series. The following Alpert ID numbers are in each AIP:

list.item: afc2017048_dc001_aip_01: audio files for Alpert 001 through Alpert 584
afc2017048_dc001_aip_02: audio files for Alpert 585 through Alpert 1179

arrangement.p: Digital surrogates of cassette liners are arranged by Alpert ID number in afc2017048_dc001_aip_01.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

scopecontent.p:
Conversations, interviews, and performances with Bronya Sakina (1910-1988), a Yiddish folk singer from Southern Ukraine. Sakina sang traditional, unaccompanied solo Yiddish folk songs. Included in this series are performances for the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, KlezKamp, Columbia-YIVO Summer Program, and the Soviet Jewish Folk Arts Program. Additional recordings of Bronya Sakina can be found in
Series 5.

scopecontent.p:
Conversations, interviews, lessons, and performances with Leon Schwartz (1901-1989), a klezmer violinist from the Bukovina region of Ukraine. Schwartz immigrated to the United States in 1921. Included in this series are performances for the Ethnic Folk Arts Center, Jewish Ethnic Music Festival, KlezKamp, YIVO Institute, Postcrypt Coffeehouse, Rodeph Sholom School, Jewish Museum, and recordings for his published album and the Soviet Jewish Folk Arts Program.
Life in a Different World
. Also included are Michael Alpert's lessons with Schwartz and recordings of Schwartz playing with his brother, Burekh Schwartz.

scopecontent.p: Conversations, interviews, rehearsals, and performances with German Goldenshteyn (1934-2006), a klezmer clarinetist from Otaci, Romania (now a part of Moldova). Goldenshteyn immigrated to the United States in 1994. Included in this series are performances for the New England Conservatory Intercultural Institute Klezmer Workshop. Mina Goldenshteyn also participated in many of the conversations.

arrangement.p: There are no digital surrogates for AFC 2017/048: SR0626 and SR0627.

scopecontent.p:
Interviews and lessons with Ben Bazyler (1922-1990), a klezmer drummer and badkhn (a traditional wedding performer). Bazyler performed as a guest artist on the 1990 album
Klezmer Music
from Alpert's ensemble, Brave Old World. Alpert also wrote an article about Bazyler, published in the book
American Klezmer: Its Roots and Offshoots
by Mark Slobin.

did.unittitle:
Kapelye Work Tape; Ben Bazyler,
June 1984

Recording location:
Ben Bazyler's home, 828 N. Hayworth Ave, Los Angeles, CA 90046.

did.unittitle: Series 5: Soviet Jewish Folk Arts Program recordings

scopecontent.p: Interviews with performers in the Soviet Jewish Folk Arts Program. Artists include Bronya Sakina, Iosif Glushkin, Tanya Lebedinskaya, Gennady Gutkin, Fanya Moshinskaya, Zyama Epshteyn, Semyon Kommisar, Borekh Shildergemeyn, Yeva Chornaya, Yefim Libovich, Khaya Sherman, Boris Legun, and Eliza Efremashvili.

scopecontent.p: Field recordings from Michael Alpert's fieldwork in Eastern Europe, primarily Romania and Ukraine. Included are interviews and conversations with performers, social gatherings, special events and celebrations, other performances, and music in monasteries.

did.didnote:
Personnel:
Zyama Epshteyn, Rakhel Datkashvili, Fanya Moshinskaya, Michael Alpert.

did.didnote: Digital copies of audio are available as both WAV and MP3 files. PDF files depicting the outside of each audio carrier are also available for many of the recordings.

scopecontent.p: Field recordings from Michael Alpert's fieldwork in North America, primarily New York City and Los Angeles. Includes interviews and conversations with performers, social gatherings, special events and celebrations, and other performances.

arrangement.p: There are no digital surrogates for AFC 2017/048: SR0628 through SR0638.

bibref.ref:
Alpert, Michael.
'All My Life a Musician': Ben Bazyler, a European Klezmer in America.
In
American Klezmer: Its Roots and Offshoots,
edited by Mark Slobin, 73-83. Berkeley: University of California Press, 2002.

Beregovski, Moshe.
Jewish Instrumental Folk Music: The Collections and Writings of Moshe Beregovski.
Edited and translated by Mark Slobin, Robert A. Rothstein, and Michael Alpert. Syracuse, NY: Syracuse University Press, 2001.
